item.title: Blake Richards
item.description: 1/ What is the organization of mouse visual cortex across regions? In our latest work led by Rudi Tong and Stuart Trenholm, now out on bioRxiv (https://biorxiv.org/content/10.1101/2023.11.03.565500v1) we mapped the "feature landscape" of mouse visual cortex.Here is a thread about what we found.#neuroscience #neuralnetworks

item.title: Blake Richards
item.description: 2/ In recent years, the mouse has become an invaluable model system for studying vision due to its technical accessibility. However, little is known about the specific visual features that mouse visual cortical areas respond to.

item.title: Blake Richards
item.description: 3/ Here, we set out to first collect the feature preferences across several mouse visual cortical areas and, subsequently, to investigate how the diversity of feature preferences in one area relates to the role that area may play in the overall visual system.

item.title: Blake Richards
item.description: 4/ We presented mice with a large set of static, natural images while performing 2-photon calcium imaging of thousands of neurons across 6 visual areas: primary visual cortex (V1), and five higher visual areas (HVAs): LM, LI, POR, AL, and RL.

item.title: Blake Richards
item.description:
5/ We modelled neuron responses using deep convolutional neural nets, adapting the ‚ÄòInception loop‚Äô technique developed by
Andreas Tolias and colleagues to generate visual stimuli that strongly activate individual neurons in each visual area.

item.title: Blake Richards
item.description: 6/ Here are some of our key findings:First, each HVA prefers a distinct set of visual features. Interestingly, we find that neurons in areas LI and POR prefer grid-like patterns, whereas AL and RL tend to prefer a single white or black line.

item.title: Blake Richards
item.description: 7/ We visualized these feature preferences across visual areas in what we call the ‚Äúfeature landscape‚Äù.

item.title: Blake Richards
item.description: 8/ Second, HVAs are organized into two distinct hierarchical processing streams. Using our AI models, we computed the representational similarity between visual areas via the partial distance correlation and visualized it using multidimensional scaling.

item.title: Blake Richards
item.description: 9/ We further show that this organization arises naturally for a system that aims to maximize invariance towards self-motion related image transformations.

item.title: Blake Richards
item.description: 10/ Finally, feature preferences of neurons within an area are organized to maximally encode differences among their own set of preferred stimuli while remaining insensitive to differences among preferred stimuli from other areas. (Complementary coding!)

item.title: Blake Richards
item.description: 11/ Importantly, we found that the set of preferred stimuli form a ‚Äòspanning set‚Äô and traversing through this set gives us a data-driven way to construct tuning curves for a population of neurons.

item.title: Blake Richards
item.description: 12/ Together, these results shed light on how the visual system is organized on both within-area and across-area levels. Future work will help us to understand how these neuronal representations of the visual world impact the mouse‚Äôs perception and guide behaviour.
